transcript: him, and could not say with certainty whether the attack had been repulsed or his regiment had been bro- ken up. All he knew was that at the commence- ment of the action balls and shells began fly- ing all over his regiment and hitting men and that afterwards someone had shouted "Caval- ry!" and our men had begun firing. They were still firing, not at the cavalry which had disap- peared, but at French infantry who had come into the hollow and were firing at our men. Prince Bagration bowed
